StringWithMarkup.String: 1-Methylnaphthalene was identified as a stack emission(1) and a component of fly ash(2) from waste incinerators. 1-Methylnaphthalene was found in the emissions from the combustion of polystyrene, polyvinyl chloride, polyethylene, polypropylene, and polymethyl methacrylate(3). Gas phase 1-methylnaphthalene emission rates from fireplace combustion of pine, oak, and eucalyptus wood were 10.6, 6.39 and 4.31 mg/kg of wood burned(4). Data from Aug 25 to Sept 7 1979 showed for a speed of 80 km/hr on straight and level highway, gasoline powered vehicles and diesel trucks emitted 1-methylnaphthalene at an average rate of 1.8 and 1.3 mg/km, respectively(5). The 1-methylnaphthalene concentration in diesel powered medium duty truck emissions in the gas phase was 378 ug/km(6). The water concentration of 1-methylnaphthalene was shown to increase from 1 to 92 ng/L as a result of motorboat traffic in a canal of a fresh water lake(7). The emission rate of 1-methylnaphthalene emitted from the vehicle fleet in the Van Nuys Tunnel in Los Angeles on Sept 21, 1993 from 6 to 10 am, during morning traffic, was 25 mg/L(8). 1-Methylnaphthalene concentrations were found to range from 2.11 to 782 ng/filter in outboard marine engine particulate matter(9). Average emission rates of various polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons were measured under the Federal Testing Procedure (FTP) driving cycle, which represents urban driving, and the REP05 driving cycle, which includes conditions outside of the FTP(10). 1-Methylnaphthalene emission rates under the FTP cycle were 2.006, 0.962, and 3.157 mg/mi for tier 0 federal emissions package, tier 1 federal emissions package, and a high emitter category(10). For the REP05 cycle, emission rates were 0.211, 0.160, and 1.353 mg/mi for the same vehicle categories, respectively(10).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Sediment from the Duwamish River delta, WA contained methylnaphthalenes at an average concentration of 160 ng/g(1). Sediments from three sites in Eagle Harbor and one at President Point, WA contained methylnaphthalenes at an average of 162, 3100, 35 and <6.5 ng/g for 4, 9, 2 and 1 sample(s), respectively(2). Sediments from Providence River, Mid-bay and Rhode Island Sound, RI contained methylnaphthalenes at an average of 66.3, 16.1 and 3.8 ng/g, respectively(3). Sediment from George's Bank contained methylnaphthalenes at an average of 2.87 ng/g(4). Methylnaphthalenes were also detected in sediments from Dohkai Bay(5) and Puget Sound(6), WA, and the Elizabeth River, VA(7). Methylnaphthalenes were detected in sediment near an offshore mutliwell platform off the Coast of Texas at concentrations of 50.4 ppb at 10 m from the platform, 55.3 ppb at 25 m from the platform, and 2.0 at >25 m from the platform(8). The average concentration of methylnaphthalenes from 11 Texas estuaries adjacent to the offshore platform site was 1.9 ppb(8). Methylnaphthalenes concentration were 14.3-81.8 ng/g dry weight and 0.8-23.8 ng/g dry weight in superficial sediment samples from the Rhone delta and the Gulf of Lions in the western Mediterranean Sea, respectively, collected in May 1987 and July 1988(9). Methylnaphthalenes in surface sediment (0.5-1.0 cm) from five sediment cores collected from a north-south transect of Lake Michigan in 1991-1993 were 13.15-76.39 ng/g dry weight(10).

StringWithMarkup.String: 1-Methylnaphthalene was identified as a volatile component of cassava(1), roasted filberts(2) and nectarines(3). StringWithMarkup.String: 1-Methylnaphthalene was detected in coal-tar from the US at 2350 mg/kg; it was not detected in coal tar samples from the UK(1). 1-Methylnaphthalene was detected at 0.136 ug/g of deposited road particles; samples were collected May to Aug 1999 at 13 locations along heavily traveled urban roadways(2). 1-Methylnaphthalene was detected at 800 ug/g in commercial gasoline(3). 1-Methylnaphthalene was detected at 0.5, 61.3, 33.9, 32.6 and 37.8 ug/g in lubricating oil from a gasoline driven automobile after driving 0, 473, 2130, 3144 and 3635 km, respectively(4). 1-Methylnaphthalene is a component of cigarette smoke condensate(5). 1-Methylnaphthalene was identified in the emissions from rubberized jute cushions used in carpeting(6). 1-Methylnaphthalene was detected in all smokeless tobacco products that were tested(ng/g dry weight); dry snuff (75.2), moist snuff (62.0), chewing tobacco (20.1), hard pellet (19.2), soft pellet (74.2), plug (18.3), loose snus (32.2) and portioned snus (43.0)(7). Methylnaphthalene has been identified as a component of tobacco smoke(8).

Section.Description: Potential way(s) in which people may come into contact with a hazardous chemical.  Examples of common exposure routes are inhalation, ingestion, skin/eye contact.

Reference: (1) NIOSH; NOES. National Occupational Exposure Survey conducted from 1981-1983. Estimated numbers of employees potentially exposed to specific agents by 2-digit standard industrial classification (SIC). Available from, as of Jan 5, 2015: https://www.cdc.gov/noes

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 12,498 workers (763 of these are female) were potentially exposed to methylnaphthalenes in the US(1). Occupational exposure to methylnaphthalenes may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where methylnaphthalenes are produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to methylnaphthalenes via inhalation of ambient air and cigarette smoke, ingestion of food and drinking water, and use of smokeless tobacco products containing methylnaphthalenes(SRC).

Reference: (1) Heikkila PR et al; Scand J Work Environ Health 13: 431-7 (1987)
(2) Gammage RB; PAH in  Workplace Environ Marcel Dekker Inc p 653-707 (1983)
(3) Bjorseth A et al; Scand J Work  Environ Health 7: 223-32 (1981)
(4) Bjorseth A et al; Scand J Work Environ Health 7: 212-23  (1978)

StringWithMarkup.String: Workers at a creosote impregnation plant for lumber were exposed to an average atmospheric concentration of methylnaphthalenes of 2.2 mg/cu m for 18 samples(1). The concentration of methylnaphthalenes in the personal air at the coal preparation area of a solvent refined coal pilot plant was 16.1, 10.4 and 19.7 ug/cu m for a welder and two operators, respectively(2). Methylnaphthalenes were found to be completely in the gaseous phase in the workplace air of an aluminum plant at Soderberg, Norway at an average of 14.04 ug/cu m(3). Methylnaphthalenes were found to be completely in the gaseous phase in the workplace air for 3 of 9, 4 of 6 and 9 of 9 samples from the anode, prebaked and vertical pin plants at an aluminum factory in Soderberg, Norway at 0.60-14.0, 1.59-22.3 and 1.22-123.53 ug/cu m, respectively(4). Methylnaphthalenes were found in both particulate and gaseous phase for the tenth sample from the vertical pin plant at 0.12 and 100.42 ug/cu m, respectively(4).

Reference: (1) Heikkila PR et al; Scand J Work Environ Health 13: 431-7 (1987)

StringWithMarkup.String: Occupational exposure to 1-methylnaphthalene may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where 1-methylnaphthalene is produced or used. Workers at a creosote impregnation plant for lumber were exposed to an average atmospheric concentration of 1-methylnaphthalene of 0.3 mg/cu m for 18 samples(1). Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to 1-methylnaphthalene via inhalation of ambient air and cigarette smoke, ingestion of food and drinking water, and dermal contact with products containing 1-methylnaphthalene(SRC).

Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

EPA Chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) collection contains information on chemicals and their regulation under TSCA. The chemical classification tree is created based on the TSCA substance regulatory flag, UVCB, and commercial activity status.
Update: 2024-12-06 12:51:01

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.

Reference.Name: SID 403030724
Reference.Description: The PATENTSCOPE database from WIPO includes patent and chemical structure search (with a free account) that gives access to millions of patent documents. The World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) is a specialized United Nations (UN) agency headquartered in Geneva (Switzerland). Our mission is to lead the development of a balanced and effective international Intellectual Property (IP) system that enables innovation and creativity for the benefit of all. We help governments, businesses and society realize the benefits of Intellectual Property and are notably a world reference source for IP information.
